Award.AwardTitle: RAPID: Understanding Evacuation, Sheltering, and Reentry Decisions During the Dual Threat of Hurricane and the COVID-19 Pandemic

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration: This Grant for Rapid Response Research (RAPID) project will study emergency mangers’ and households’ evacuation decisions and their sheltering considerations during Hurricane Laura as individuals cope with the COVID-19 pandemic. It is important for the scientific community, policymakers, and emergency managers to understand how the simultaneous threats of a hurricane and a pandemic affect individual and household decisions about protecting themselves during these events. The findings from this project will help emergency managers and policymakers develop appropriate public health and population protection strategies to help communities be prepared for future events. With a better understating of the determinants of hurricane and pandemic protective actions (e.g. evacuation, social distancing, sheltering) compliance, emergency managers can develop better evacuation plans and warning messages to help reduce the impact of both the pandemic and hurricane, as well as to advance national health and welfare. More specifically, the scientific progress generated by this research will increase understanding of differences between emergency mangers’ and citizens’ concerns regarding the maintenance of shelters, sheltering locations (public shelters, hotels, friends’, and relatives’ house), evacuation routing, and evacuation modeling during a pandemic. Emergency managers will be able to better design and locate shelters and encourage households to take appropriate protective actions in the future when facing similar threats.<br/> <br/>This project will advance the state of science about households’ and emergency mangers’ protective action decision-making processes by using a sequential mixed methods design. This study will use survey and interview methodologies to collect both quantitative and qualitative data from emergency managers and households in the Hurricane Laura risk areas in Texas and Louisiana. Because of the complexity of the event, this project requires the integration of variables in both the Protection Motivation Theory and the Protective Action Decision Model. The results of this study will build a new theoretical model that captures individuals’ protective action decision-making process in a dual hazard environment (hurricane and pandemic). This project will contribute to emerging research on pandemics and disasters in the United States, but with a focus on how the pandemic is shaping protective action decision-making, which has generalizability to other compound events.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This Rapid Response Research (RAPID) project investigates the evacuation decisions of emergency managers and households, along with their considerations for sheltering during Hurricane Laura, as individuals coped with the COVID-19 pandemic. It is crucial for the scientific community, policymakers, and emergency managers to understand how the concurrent threats of a hurricane and a pandemic impact individual and household protective action decisions during these events.

Intellectual merit: This research addresses a gap in the hazard risk perception literature by examining the associations among different aspects of threat perception and their effects on evacuation decisions. The findings contributed to risk theories that could be used for future situations where an environmental hazard is intertwined with respiratory infectious disease risk. Evacuation is an important protective action choice before, during, and after disasters such as hurricanes, floods, tsunamis, or wildfires. Project findings can be applied to ongoing and future studies focused on developing programs that facilitate a more efficient evacuation decision process. Additionally, the confluence of Hurricane Laura and COVID-19 posed a novel challenge for emergency management stakeholders. This study attempts to understand how COVID-19 affected emergency management operations in response to a familiar hazard. In general, evidence of improvisation was found during the planning process among key stakeholders for hurricane season, the evacuation effort, and the sheltering operations in both Texas and Louisiana. Participants described a system that operated on inertia, adhering to normal hurricane planning and response operations until outside forces necessitated a change. Improvisation in the planning process in response to COVID-19 precautions and improvisation in the hurricane response was tied to attempts to address a last-minute shift to non-congregate sheltering imposed by their respective states. This improvisation led to varying approaches across the states in the evacuation effort, and each state encountered several challenges in managing the distributed evacuation effort remotely. Given the continued threat posed by COVID-19 and other respiratory illnesses, this study provides insights that emergency management stakeholders could apply to current and future planning and response efforts for hazards requiring evacuation and sheltering.

Broader Impact: The findings from this project can help emergency managers and policymakers develop appropriate public health and population protection strategies to prepare communities for future events. With a better understanding of the determinants of hurricane and pandemic protective actions compliance (e.g., evacuation, social distancing, sheltering), emergency managers can develop better evacuation plans and warning messages to reduce the impact of both the pandemic and hurricanes, as well as to advance national health and welfare. Specifically, the scientific progress generated by this research will increase understanding of the differences between emergency managers' and citizens' concerns regarding the maintenance of shelters, sheltering locations, evacuation routing, and evacuation modeling during a pandemic. Emergency managers will be better able to design and locate shelters and encourage households to take appropriate protective actions in the future when facing similar threats. Furthermore, the project's data is currently accessible upon request and will be deposited in an open-source data repository, DesignSafe-CI, within a year after the project concludes. The project findings have been successfully published in two major peer-review journals in the field of risk research and a technical report was published by the Natural Hazard Center. In addition, we delivered six conference presentations during the grant period. The materials used for data collection are employed in all the investigators' universities for a range of courses, including Introduction to Emergency Management and Disaster Science, Research Methods, Risk Analysis, etc. Additionally, the project has supported minority and female students pursuing their Masters and Ph.D. degrees.
